content.description:
Climb the leftmost crack system to the bolts. Line #2 (pic # 1) is a TR that climbs right of this and shares the holds of Wing Tip and

Leading Beta

.
content.protection:
Eds. When the submission was entered, it was listed as having 3 bolts, but appears to be the route to the right, Off The Hook. Confusion appears to stem from a newer guidebook that is not correct.

Per

Alex Morano

: bring a standard rack with extra small nuts.
content.location: This is the left line on the main boulder.

content.description:
This is a classic bouldering route on the main boulder. The line shares a start hold of the

Circle of Life

and then moves out low and left and then up and finishes on the same finish as

COL

. You just step off onto the boulder behind at the finish.
content.location: It is the leftmost line on the boulder. Start sitting.

content.description: This is an awesome line that involves a fingery traverse, committing moves to jugs, and laybacks on small yet positive sidepulls.
content.location: It is the second farthest right bolted line and shares the first bolt with the route to the left. It is then an independent line to the top.

content.description: A burly overhung section leads to a fun broken dihedral. Hardware could use an update.
content.location: It climbs the left side the boulder, beginning in an overhungish crack.

content.description: Start low with both of your hands on the arete. A good left foot will get you off the ground. Climb to the horn, and traverse right to an incut rail. Climb the easy slab up and left. Walk off.
content.location: At the right side of Hummingbird's main wall, take a left, and about 40 feet up you will get to a small cave. This line is the arete.

content.description:
Use small holds and techy movements to work straight up. End with a leftward "leap of faith" to the jug leading to the anchors.

You can set up a toprope without leading Wing Tip. Scramble up the climber's right side of the boulder, and carefully make your way to the bolted anchors.
content.protection: A toprope. This shares anchors with Off the Hook.
content.location: The chalked up face just right of Off The Hook.

content.description: Start low on some crimps, and traverse up and right all the way to the big, chalky jug. Then go low and back to the start, then go up, finish up the seam, and step off on the boulder.
content.location: It is in the center of the boulder and traverses right to the jug then back right.

content.description: Start low with your right hand on slopey, triangle crimp and your left hand on good sidepull. Move up the bulge without using the left arete. Top put on good holds near a raspberry bush.
content.location: It is up and right from the main Hummingbird Wall.

content.description:
Crazy Horse is similar to its bigger brother,

Triple P

, but less sustained. Powerful moves between bigs jugs make this climb a blast. The rock was a little chossy when I was cleaning the route. I would wear helmets, and be prepared for small stuff to come loose. I spent two hours scrubbing lichen and moss off this route, but I’m sure some of you want spotless routes. If you can’t handle a little dirty climbing, I would bring a brush and clean the holds before you attempt a lead. Despite its flaws, it’s a fun route worth working the moves out for!

Look for a somewhat high first  bolt. You might want a stickclip, but the moves to the bolt are 5.8. The anchors for this climb are up the slab. There is probably a 15 foot runout, but the climbing is pretty much fourth class. DON’T try and use the anchors from

Triple P

!
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor on the slab.
content.location: It is the furthest right line on the wall.

climbs.name: Between a Rock and a Hard Place

content.description: This is the three bolt sport climb that goes up the middle of the wall.
